stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions?

options.text: Increasing serum ammonia levels from 200 mcg/dL to 220 mcg/dL.
Decreasing heart rate from 110 bpm to 90 bpm.
Improved Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score from 8 to 12.
Worsening ascites with increased abdominal girth.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
TimeNote
0800Patient lethargic, GCS 8, responds to painful stimuli. Asterixis present. Serum ammonia 200 mcg/dL. Ascites noted.
0930Patient more responsive, GCS 10, responds to verbal stimuli. Asterixis less pronounced. Serum ammonia 180 mcg/dL.
1100Patient alert and oriented to person, GCS 12, follows simple commands. Asterixis absent. Serum ammonia 160 mcg/dL.

tabs.title: Orders
tabs.content:
• Lactulose 30 mL PO every 4 hours
  • Neomycin 1 gram PO every 6 hours
  • Monitor ammonia levels every 4 hours
  • Assess level of consciousness every 2 hours

rationale.correctRationale: An improved Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score from 8 to 12 indicates improved neurological function. In the context of liver failure, this improvement is likely due to a reduction in serum ammonia levels secondary to the treatment with lactulose and neomycin. Hepatic encephalopathy is a complication of liver failure caused by the buildup of ammonia in the bloodstream, leading to altered mental status and decreased level of consciousness. An increasing GCS score indicates that the interventions are effectively reducing ammonia levels and improving brain function.

incorrectRationales.option_1: Increasing serum ammonia levels indicate a worsening condition, not a therapeutic response. The goal of treatment is to lower ammonia levels.
incorrectRationales.option_2: While a decreasing heart rate can be a positive sign, it is not the most direct indicator of a therapeutic response to interventions aimed at reducing ammonia levels and improving neurological function in hepatic encephalopathy. A change in heart rate could be related to various factors and is not as specific as the GCS score in this context.
incorrectRationales.option_4: Worsening ascites indicates a lack of therapeutic response, not an improvement. Ascites is a common complication of liver failure and indicates fluid retention due to impaired liver function.

rationale.clinicalPearls: In patients with liver failure and hepatic encephalopathy, monitor neurological status closely. Serial ammonia levels and GCS scores are crucial indicators of treatment effectiveness. Lactulose and neomycin are commonly used to reduce ammonia levels and improve mental status.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may choose options related to vital signs that are improving (e.g., heart rate) without recognizing the direct relationship between ammonia levels, neurological status, and the effectiveness of interventions for hepatic encephalopathy. Focus on the primary problem (elevated ammonia) and the most direct indicator of improvement (GCS).
rationale.mnemonic: GCS: Good Condition Status (higher score = better).
